headline.main: Beijing Journal;   With Fish as Bait, the Leaders Troll for Approval

docs.snippet: LEAD: As one lunar year fades into another, the emblem of the holiday seems to be fish - live, frozen, bagged or wrapped in an old newspaper - and city dwellers carry packs of them on the fronts and backs of their bicycles, already weighed down by ot

byline.original: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: As one lunar year fades into another, the emblem of the holiday seems to be fish - live, frozen, bagged or wrapped in an old newspaper - and city dwellers carry packs of them on the fronts and backs of their bicycles, already weighed down by other bounty of the Chinese New Year.

headline.main: Students Find U.S. Embassy a Barrier

docs.snippet: LEAD: In his news conference on Wednesday, President Bush pleaded with Congress not to ease the visa rules for Chinese students now in the United States. One of his arguments was that the action might lead China to cut back on future programs of stud

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In his news conference on Wednesday, President Bush pleaded with Congress not to ease the visa rules for Chinese students now in the United States. One of his arguments was that the action might lead China to cut back on future programs of study abroad, which he characterized as an important force for change in China.

headline.main: U.S. Report Accuses China of Grave Rights Abuses

docs.snippet: LEAD: In a sharp departure from the Bush Administration's cautious statements on China, a confidential State Department report says there were pervasive, severe violations of human rights in Beijing, Tibet and other parts of China last year.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In a sharp departure from the Bush Administration's cautious statements on China, a confidential State Department report says there were pervasive, severe violations of human rights in Beijing, Tibet and other parts of China last year.

headline.main: Shanghai Journal;   Lost in Thought in the Land of Thought Control

docs.snippet: LEAD: Last fall, when a minor official of the Communist Party wanted to gauge the severity of the campaign against intellectuals, she asked about the writer Bai Hua. ''Is he in jail?'' she wanted to know, and when she heard that he had been left alon

byline.original: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Last fall, when a minor official of the Communist Party wanted to gauge the severity of the campaign against intellectuals, she asked about the writer Bai Hua. ''Is he in jail?'' she wanted to know, and when she heard that he had been left alone, she relaxed and said, ''Things can't be that bad.''

headline.main: U.S. Official Urges 'Real World' View of China

docs.snippet: LEAD: Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger asked Congress today to take a more tolerant view of China, saying it was ''less completely evil'' than it seemed in June, when the Chinese Army crushed the democracy movement in Beijing.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger asked Congress today to take a more tolerant view of China, saying it was ''less completely evil'' than it seemed in June, when the Chinese Army crushed the democracy movement in Beijing.

docs.snippet: LEAD: WHO would be the first to mention Tiananmen Square, I wondered as I embarked on a 12-day tour of China in December with 33 other Americans - one of the first large tourist groups back in China since the events of last June 4. The speculation wa

byline.original: By CAROL KRAMER; CAROL KRAMER is an editor of 7 Days, a New York weekly

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: WHO would be the first to mention Tiananmen Square, I wondered as I embarked on a 12-day tour of China in December with 33 other Americans - one of the first large tourist groups back in China since the events of last June 4. The speculation was incredibly naive.

docs.snippet: LEAD: Despite the lifting of martial law in the capital last month, the Chinese authorities appear to have intensified their efforts to keep foreign journalists under surveillance and limit their unofficial contacts with Chinese, Beijing-based corres

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Despite the lifting of martial law in the capital last month, the Chinese authorities appear to have intensified their efforts to keep foreign journalists under surveillance and limit their unofficial contacts with Chinese, Beijing-based correspondents and some Chinese say.

headline.main: Signs of Spring in China, and New Discontent

docs.snippet: LEAD: In the first sign that Chinese dissidents are planning protests this spring, students said illegal posters were put up today at two or more universities, calling for peaceful demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in the coming week.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: In the first sign that Chinese dissidents are planning protests this spring, students said illegal posters were put up today at two or more universities, calling for peaceful demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in the coming week.

headline.main: Beijing Seals Off Square; Protest Fizzles

docs.snippet: LEAD: Faced with the threat of renewed protests in Tiananmen Square, the authorities sealed the area to the general public today while arranging for thousands of schoolchildren to sing and dance in the square.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Faced with the threat of renewed protests in Tiananmen Square, the authorities sealed the area to the general public today while arranging for thousands of schoolchildren to sing and dance in the square.

docs.snippet: LEAD: The authorities sealed off Tiananmen Square again today, the second time this week, to prevent people from holding quiet rallies to remember the pro-democracy protesters killed by army troops in June.      Today was Tomb-Sweeping
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The authorities sealed off Tiananmen Square again today, the second time this week, to prevent people from holding quiet rallies to remember the pro-democracy protesters killed by army troops in June. Today was Tomb-Sweeping
